title: Neuter Plurals (-o -> -a)
reading_greek:
GROUP 1: -O NOUNS (The most common)
Το βιβλίο -> Τα βιβλία
Το νερό -> Τα νερά
Το μήλο -> Τα μήλα (Apples)

GROUP 2: -I NOUNS (The 'iota' nouns)
Το παιδί -> Τα παιδιά (Children)
Το σπίτι -> Τα σπίτια (Houses)
Το λουλούδι -> Τα λουλούδια (Flowers)

GROUP 3: -MA NOUNS (The 'expansion' nouns)
Το όνομα -> Τα ονόματα (Names)
Το πρόβλημα -> Τα προβλήματα (Problems)
Το μάθημα -> Τα μαθήματα (Lessons)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: NEUTER PLURALS [(See Page 45)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=45)

1. THE ARTICLE: Always 'Ta'. 
   - Singular: To. Plural: Ta. 
   - Easy!

2. GROUP 1 (-o -> -a): 
   - Just change the o to a. (Vivlio -> Vivlia).

3. GROUP 2 (-i -> -ia): 
   - Add an alpha. (Paidi -> Paidia).

4. GROUP 3 (-ma -> -mata):
   - These words get longer! They add a syllable.
   - Onoma -> Onomata.
   - This is very common for Greek concepts (Provlima, Mathima, Systima).
audio_script:
Neuter nouns are special. 

First, the Article is simple: 'To' becomes 'Ta'. 
And importantly: Neuter Nouns are IDENTICAL in Subject and Object. 
'Ta vivlia einai edo' (subject). 'Exo ta vivlia' (object). No change!

The Noun Endings have 3 distinct groups:
1. Words in -o become -a. (Vuvlio -> Vivlia).
2. Words in -i become -ia. (Spiti -> Spitia). Don't forget the 'i' sound!
3. Words in -ma grow longer. They become -mata. 
   - 'To Onoma' (Name) -> 'Ta Onomata'. 
   - 'To Mathima' (Lesson) -> 'Ta Mathimata'.

quiz_questions.question: What is the plural of 'Το βιβλίο'?
What is the plural of 'Το παιδί'?
What is the plural of 'Το μάθημα'?
Is 'Ta' used for Subject or Object?
quiz_questions.explanation: Neuter nouns never change between Subject/Object.
